meaning: The word 'again' means once more; another time; in addition; back to the original place or condition.
etymology: The word 'again' originates from the Old English 'onġēan', which means 'toward, opposite, against, in return'. It is derived from the Proto-Germanic *gagin, meaning 'against, back', and is related to the Old High German 'gagan' and Old Norse 'gegn'.
sentences: She decided to try again after her first attempt failed.
Famous quote: 'If at first you don't succeed, try, try again.' - W.E. Hickson
short_stories: A short story titled 'The Phoenix' by Sylvia Townsend Warner features the theme of rebirth and starting 'again', symbolizing renewal and resilience.
Another story, 'The Lottery' by Shirley Jackson, subtly hints at the cyclical nature of traditions, suggesting that the events will happen 'again' the following year.
poetry: Poem: 'Do Not Go Gentle into That Good Night' by Dylan Thomas - The phrase 'Rage, rage against the dying of the light' can be interpreted as a call to fight 'again' against the inevitable.
Poem: 'Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening' by Robert Frost - The repetition of 'And miles to go before I sleep' emphasizes the journey that must be undertaken 'again'.
